H0.text: Increased cellular temperature is how the body converts information from the environment to an internal response for animals that respond to environmental stimuli obtained through their sensory organs.

H1.text: Selective membrane transport is the process by which animals convert information from environmental stimuli obtained through their sensory organs into an internal response.

H2.text: Chemical signaling is the process by which the body converts information from environmental stimuli obtained through sensory organs into an internal response.

H3.text: Osmotic pressure is how the body converts information from environmental stimuli obtained through sensory organs to an internal response.

A4.text: The sensing of temperature in cells is known as thermoception and is primarily mediated by transient receptor potential channels.

A5.text: The binding of a signaling molecule with a receptor causes a change in the conformation of the receptor, known as receptor activation.

A6.text: Netpath is a curated resource of signal transduction pathways in humans.

A7.text: TRANSPATH(R) is a database about signal transduction pathways.
